div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell, Friday May 14th 1915
div1.p: A lot of very severe fighting during the last few days has resulted in a great deal of work for us and hence no time to write.
There isn’t much news anyway, save that regarding operations and we naturally can’t write along that line.

I was very much pleased the other day
to have a Mr. Terry (I don’t know the French spelling of his name) tell me that he had heard from the Vicomte du Peloux and that he had asked him to tell me you had been given a very long leave. I’m “sure” pleased to hear it, tho [sic] I’d rather you had been made reforme, of course. It was exceptionally nice and
thoughtful of the Vicomte to get the news out to me. In your letter, which I received the day before, you stated you were going before the Commission the next day.
Mr. Terry is a charming man to talk with. I believe he’s been in diplomatic work. He speaks English perfectly.

We’re now living all the time at our advance point for the work has become so heavy that we all of us have to be on the job night and day. I told you, didn’t I, that the French section had been ordered away to another point and that now we do all the work. We are to have six new cars and as many drivers by next
Wednesday.

The Germans are paying us a bit more attention now and certain people are getting out. There was a shop where very delicious Madelines could be obtained. A shell hit the place the other day and now we can buy no Madelines. We had electric lights, but an obus clipped our wires and now we have but gas.
It certainly is a gay old time after a charge, isn’t it? Up at the Postes de Secours where the soldiers have come down for a little while to rest the scene is certainly a queer one, and there is a moving quality to the atmosphere that does not usually exist. I saw one fellow, the blood streaming down his face from a head wound, wearing
a captured German helmet tacking up and down the road soused to the gills. The great mob of soldiers all around are raising a great lot of noise, yelling at anything and there isn’t a thing they wouldn’t do for you. He’s a great fellow, the French soldier; so
full of different sentiments. The other morning at sunrise a dying man was given me. His comrades gathered around my car and said “Bon voyage mon vieux et bonne chance.” And their voices were soft, for they saw death coming into his face. When I arrived at the hospital I found that the soldiers had stuck sprigs of lilac around my car.

closer.salute:
My sincere regards to the Vicomte
Yours
